SD applauds the issue's incorporation of Committee of Regions' input as fully consistent with S&D's governance model prioritizing multi-level decision-making and subsidiarity principles.  
SD emphasizes the critical need for swift operationalization of simplified funding procedures to maximize youth employment initiatives outlined in the European Social Fund provisions.

GUE_NGL partly approves the EGTC reform but demands removal of Article 7's macroeconomic conditionality, which weaponizes cohesion funds to enforce austerity—fully condemning with their anti-neoliberal governance principles.  

GUE_NGL requests revisions to prioritize social infrastructure in Article 4, opposing the current focus on private-sector projects like airports and energy monopolies that neglect housing, healthcare, and worker needs.  

GUE_NGL highlights the undemocratic bypassing of amendments on funding suspensions, overlooking critical safeguards against poverty escalation in crisis-hit regions as outlined in their 2022 cohesion manifesto.  

GUE_NGL criticizes the diluted ESF allocation (20% poverty target) as inconsistent with their demand for binding 25% minimums, urging stricter wording to prevent employability metrics from overriding direct social inclusion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning regional development and external action, adopting its first reading stance as outlined in the Committee on Regional Development’s report (A7-0309/2013). The resolution emphasized alignment with Treaty provisions, particularly Articles 175, 209(1), and 212(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which govern EU action in economic, social, and territorial cohesion, as well as development and external cooperation. It called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the original 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0610/2) were planned, ensuring legislative transparency. The Parliament also instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence under EU legislative frameworks. The resolution integrated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2012) and the Committee of the Regions (February 2012), reflecting stakeholder input while focusing on substantive policy coherence and institutional accountability.

title: General provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund as regards simplification of certain requirements and as regards certain provisions relating to financial management: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending regulation (EC) No 1083/2006 concerning general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund as regards simplification of certain requirements and as regards provisions relating to financial management
background: The European Union faced economic crisis impacts, administrative complexities in Structural Funds management, and delayed absorption of cohesion policy resources, prompting calls for streamlined procedures. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to simplify financial management and access requirements for the European Regional Development, Social, and Cohesion Funds.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely promotes the issue's alignment with Treaty provisions and interinstitutional cooperation, perfectly reflecting their commitment to cohesive EU governance.  
EPP applauds the crisis-response measures including financial advances and extended fund utilization periods, which directly advance regional economic stability priorities.  
EPP emphasizes the issue’s success in preserving cofinancing mechanisms as essential for shared responsibility in regional development projects.  
EPP recognizes the procedural acceleration as critical for tangible results, converting past bureaucratic challenges into streamlined implementation frameworks.  
EPP highlights the issue’s foundational role in future policy architecture, urging continued simplification efforts post-2013 while maintaining current achievements.

GREEN_EFA totally disputes the increased threshold for project evaluations, as it eliminates mandatory environmental compliance checks and transparent cost-benefit analyses, directly conflicting with principles of ecological accountability.  
GREEN_EFA rejects reduced sustainability requirements for SMEs, demanding five-year commitments instead of three to prevent transient subsidy exploitation as seen in the Nokia case.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposal’s allowance of non-transparent project assessments, which overlooks critical public oversight mechanisms enshrined in EU environmental legislation.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s failure to address disproportionate financial burdens on regions, enabling risky debt structures that violate fiscal responsibility commitments.  
GREEN_EFA insists on maintaining ex-ante evaluations for all major projects, asserting that weakened scrutiny fundamentally undermines taxpayer trust in Structural Funds management.

ALDE completely agrees the issue’s prioritization of the European Social Fund’s crisis-response capacity, perfectly aligning with their commitment to combat unemployment through targeted workforce development.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the advance payment mechanisms for liquidity support, recognizing their critical role in accelerating economic recovery for crisis-impacted Member States.  
ALDE strongly advocates the streamlined fund accessibility provisions, which effectively advance their priority of reducing bureaucratic barriers to EU-funded social and cohesion initiatives.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s alignment with lifelong learning strategies, reinforcing their advocacy for adaptable workforce training in a globalized economy.  
ALDE commends the focus on marginalized groups through ESF allocations, reflecting their longstanding dedication to inclusive social policy and equitable resource distribution.

GUE_NGL rejects the inadequate crisis response measures that fail to implement full interim payments for labor market policies as originally proposed by the Commission  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the compromised provisions that neglect urgent unemployment challenges across all Member States beyond the five prioritized countries  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's inconsistency with their demand for maximal Structural Fund utilization to counteract rising poverty and precarious employment conditions  
GUE_NGL condemns the missed opportunity to operationalize Article 161's potential through binding mechanisms for social protection in cohesion spending  
GUE_NGL underscores the proposal's failure to address systemic underinvestment in public services critical to GUE/NGL's anti-austerity platform

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a proposed regulation concerning regional development, emphasizing alignment with Treaty provisions and interinstitutional procedures following the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force. It adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacement of the proposal (COM(2009)0384) were planned, ensuring legislative transparency and continuity. The resolution highlighted collaboration with the Committee on Regional Development, incorporating opinions from the Committees on Budgets and Employment and Social Affairs, and stressed adherence to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 294(3) and 177) and the EC Treaty (Article 161). It mandated forwarding the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural accountability while prioritizing regional policy coherence and institutional cooperation.

title: Implementation of the synergies of research and innovation earmarked funds in Regulation (EC) No 1080/2006 concerning the European Fund of Regional Development and the Seventh Framework Programme for Research and Development: REPORT on the implementation of the synergies of research and innovation earmarked Funds in Regulation (EC) No 1080/2006 concerning the European Fund of Regional Development and the Seventh Framework Programme for Research and Development in cities and regions as well as in the Member States and the Union
background: The European Regional Development Fund and Seventh Framework Programme allocated significant EU resources for research, innovation, and regional development, aligned with Lisbon Strategy goals for competitiveness. Institutional frameworks emphasized cohesion policy alongside excellence-based research funding. The Parliament will discuss optimizing coordination between structural funds and research programmes to strengthen innovation capacities across EU regions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on integrated governance and multi-level coordination, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to reinforcing economic union through strengthened political cohesion and cross-policy synergies.  
EPP approves the harmonization of Structural Funds with FP7 and CIP for infrastructure development, proposing enhanced SME access to mixed funding streams through simplified application portals.  
EPP endorses the prioritization of smart specialization strategies in regions, matching EPP's manifesto focus on place-based innovation ecosystems and territorial cohesion.  
EPP highlights the need to operationalize fiscal discipline mechanisms alongside growth initiatives, urging stricter Stability and Growth Pact enforcement to complement R&D investments.  
EPP emphasizes resolving administrative barriers as critical enhancement opportunities, advocating for real-time digital reporting systems to reduce bureaucratic delays in fund disbursement.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on multi-level governance and smart specialization strategies, which align perfectly with their advocacy for place-based green innovation ecosystems in urban and rural regions.  

GREEN_EFA approves the call for harmonizing Structural Funds with FP7/CIP but proposes explicitly mandating 30% of such synergies to target low-carbon infrastructure and circular economy clusters, enhancing alignment with climate goals.  

GREEN_EFA endorses the prioritization of cities as sustainable growth hubs and urges amendment to Article 4 to include binding metrics for green job creation through ERDF-funded urban innovation projects.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on transnational cooperation while recommending the issue integrate macro-regional strategies (e.g., Baltic, Danube) as formal implementation mechanisms for cross-border knowledge transfer.  

GREEN_EFA welcomes criticism of mixed funding barriers and suggests adding explicit provisions for joint FP7-SF financing of community-led renewable energy R&D, addressing democratic access to innovation resources.

SD strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on integrated governance and multi-level coordination, which aligns perfectly with S&D's commitment to territorial cohesion and reducing regional disparities through smart specialization strategies.  
SD approves the call for harmonizing Structural Funds with FP7/CIP frameworks, proposing enhanced monitoring mechanisms to ensure transparent allocation of unspent funds to high-impact regional innovation projects.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to prioritize social dimensions within the 2020 Strategy, urging explicit integration of gender equality targets and poverty reduction metrics into Member States' operational programs.  
SD endorses the urban focus as central to sustainable growth, strongly advocating for expanded JEREMIE-style instruments to empower cities as laboratories for green job creation and low-carbon infrastructure development.  
SD highlights the necessity to convert austerity critiques into proactive investment mandates, suggesting amendments to prioritize ESF allocations for upskilling programs that address youth unemployment and demographic challenges.

GUE/NGL rejects fundamentally the issue's alignment with the EU 2020 strategy's growth paradigm that perpetuates austerity measures and financial market prioritization over social protections.  
GUE/NGL opposes the failure to incorporate binding poverty reduction targets or worker protections against precarious employment in structural fund allocations.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's endorsement of Stability Pact frameworks that enable IMF-imposed austerity rather than proposing wealth redistribution mechanisms.  
GUE/NGL denounces the continued reliance on liberalization policies that accelerate privatization of public services through cohesion funding instruments.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue's democratic deficit in excluding parliamentary oversight of EU 2020 implementation, mirroring citizens' marginalization in crisis responses.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of cohesion policy, research frameworks (FP7), and innovation programs (CIP) in advancing the EU’s competitiveness, growth, and territorial cohesion, particularly through synergies between these instruments. It highlighted that €86 billion from Structural Funds (SF) was allocated to research and innovation (R&D&I) for 2007-2013, with €50 billion dedicated to core R&D, rivaling FP7’s €50.5 billion and CIP’s €3.6 billion. Emphasizing the need for integrated governance, the resolution stressed multi-level coordination to address disparities between regions, enhance innovation capacity, and align policies with the EU 2020 Strategy’s goals of smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth. It called for simplifying administrative procedures, harmonizing funding rules, and improving synergies through joint strategies, such as combining SF with FP7 and CIP for infrastructure, clusters, and knowledge transfer. The Parliament urged regions to adopt place-based innovation strategies, prioritize smart specialization, and leverage cities as hubs for sustainable growth, noting that 80% of Europeans live in urban areas. It welcomed initiatives like JEREMIE and Risk Sharing Finance Facility to boost SME financing but criticized barriers to mixed funding between SF and FP7. Future recommendations included strengthening territorial cohesion, enhancing transnational cooperation, allocating unspent SF to regional projects, and ensuring peer reviews for large SF-funded research infrastructures. The resolution underscored the need for streamlined bureaucracy, better communication of funding opportunities, and alignment of future programs (e.g., EU 2020’s Innovation Union, Youth on the Move) with SF to maximize impact on jobs, education, and low-carbon innovation.

title: Motions for resolutions - EU strategy for the Atlantic region: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the European Strategy for the Atlantic Region
background: In June 2010, the European Council mandated the Commission to develop an EU Atlantic strategy, following precedents like the Baltic and Danube strategies. Five EU states (France, Ireland, Portugal, Spain, UK) share Atlantic coastlines, with maritime activities and territorial cohesion objectives under EU treaties. The Parliament will discuss formulating an integrated EU strategy addressing Atlantic maritime and territorial cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP totally accepts the issue's integration of maritime and territorial cohesion priorities, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to multi-level governance and leveraging existing cohesion frameworks.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the emphasis on marine energy and climate action, recognizing the Atlantic's strategic role in advancing renewable technologies central to EPP's 2020 energy transition goals.  
EPP fully supports the inclusive territorial approach encompassing Macaronesia's outermost regions, reflecting EPP's principle of equitable development for all EU peripheries.  
EPP endorses the bottom-up governance model involving local authorities and EGTC tools, mirroring EPP's advocacy for subsidiarity in EU policymaking.  
EPP applauds the issue's geopolitical focus on Atlantic trade corridors and maritime security, which directly advance EPP's vision of a globally competitive EU.

GREEN_EFA completely promotes the issue’s emphasis on marine spatial planning as a cornerstone for harmonizing sectoral interests, perfectly aligning with their commitment to ecosystem-based maritime governance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for transboundary cooperation to combat microscopic plastic pollution and illegal fishing, recognizing these as critical to achieving the environmental prosperity central to the Atlantic strategy.  
GREEN_EFA completely promotes the prioritization of marine energy interconnectors and maritime transport networks, which advance both climate objectives and regional economic resilience as outlined in their renewable energy advocacy.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s integration of a bottom-up approach, ensuring local stakeholders shape policies that directly affect coastal communities’ ecological and socioeconomic futures.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s alignment with their vision for multi-level governance, particularly through tools like the EGTC, to strengthen territorial cohesion without requiring new financial instruments.

SD completely promotes the Atlantic strategy’s alignment with climate action and sustainable development priorities, perfectly reflecting S&D’s commitment to territorial cohesion and green transition.  
SD perfectly aligns with integrating maritime safety enhancements for the Channel’s strategic gateway, proposing strengthened European coordination to address transport density and offshore energy synergies.  
SD fully supports the strategy’s geopolitical focus on Atlantic connectivity to global markets, endorsing innovation in marine energy and biotechnology as critical to S&D’s economic resilience agenda.  
SD endorses the issue’s multi-level governance model, emphasizing the necessity of regional authority participation to advance cohesion policy and stakeholder-driven implementation.  
SD highlights the imperative of including Macaronesia’s outermost regions, aligning with S&D’s territorial equity principles to ensure no community is marginalized in EU-wide strategies.

ECR rejects the strategy's failure to mandate rigorous evaluation of existing INTERREG and cohesion programmes before launching new initiatives, conflicting with fiscal responsibility principles.  
ECR opposes the issue's omission of binding trans-Atlantic cooperation frameworks with the United States, a critical gap given shared Euro-Atlantic security and trade priorities.  
ECR fundamentally objects to the strategy's implicit reliance on EU funding expansion rather than reprioritising current budgets, contradicting austerity commitments.  
ECR condemns the lack of measurable safeguards against duplicative bureaucracy, which risks undermining national sovereignty in coastal management.  
ECR disputes the geopolitical relevance claims, arguing the text inadequately addresses NATO coordination and fails to counter third-state influence in Atlantic maritime zones.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for an integrated EU strategy for the Atlantic region, encompassing maritime and territorial issues, to enhance territorial cohesion and cooperation among five Atlantic Member States (France, Ireland, Portugal, Spain, and the UK). It emphasized leveraging existing cohesion policy frameworks, particularly Objective 3 (territorial cooperation), to coordinate multi-level governance, optimize funding without additional resources, and align with the EU 2020 strategy and post-2013 policies. The resolution highlighted priorities such as marine energy, climate action, maritime safety, transport networks (including short-sea shipping and projects like the Gijón-Nantes maritime road to reduce CO2 emissions), fisheries, tourism, and research. It stressed inclusivity for all Atlantic coastal regions, including Macaronesia’s outermost regions, and advocated for a bottom-up approach involving local authorities, stakeholders, and civil society. The strategy’s external dimension was noted for its geopolitical relevance in trade and security, while internal coordination with EU policies (e.g., maritime, energy, transport) was deemed critical. Simplified rules, multi-level governance, and the use of tools like the European Grouping of Territorial Cooperation (EGTC) were recommended to streamline implementation from 2014 onward, aligned with the next multiannual financial framework. The Parliament urged the Commission to prioritize synergies across policies, ensure efficient fund allocation, and maintain regular consultation with Parliament during strategy development.

title: Good governance and EU regional policy: REPORT on good governance with regards to the EU regional policy: procedures of assistance and control by the European Commission
background: The European Court of Auditors identified persistent irregularities in Structural Funds expenditure, prompting the European Commission to initiate supervisory reforms. Existing EU cohesion policy frameworks aimed to address regional disparities but faced challenges from administrative complexity and evolving geopolitical pressures. The Parliament will discuss governance mechanisms in EU regional policy, focusing on Commission assistance and control procedures.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely upholds the issue's emphasis on compulsory multi-level governance across EU territorial policies, perfectly aligning with their decades-long advocacy for decentralized decision-making and regional legislative empowerment.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the strengthened partnership principle requiring Member States to formally consult regional authorities on development priorities, as emphasized by Olbrycht's call for binding partnership agreements in cohesion contracts.  
EPP fully supports the issue's demand for simplified funding architectures and lump-sum payments, mirroring Teixeira and Kelly's arguments for reducing administrative complexity to accelerate fund absorption.  
EPP endorses the territorial cohesion mechanisms for cross-border cooperation, echoing Matera and Mikolášik's emphasis on leveraging border regions' economic synergies through streamlined partnerships.  
EPP fully backs the issue's integration of cohesion policy with EU2020 strategy goals, aligning with Kozłowski and Jahr's insistence on measurable outcomes for regional competitiveness and crisis resilience.

GREEN_EFA completely upholds the issue's integration of sustainable low-carbon economy principles and biodiversity safeguards, perfectly aligning with their environmental transition priorities.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on multi-level governance and civil society partnerships, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for regional empowerment and participatory decision-making.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's advancement of ecological innovation through research frameworks, advocating for explicit prioritization of green economy metrics in competitiveness strategies.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the administrative capacity-building measures, including the "Erasmus for elected local representatives," as a critical step toward equitable regional governance aligned with their principles.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the rejection of cohesion policy renationalization and sustained EU funding post-2013, ensuring continuity in addressing territorial disparities through green investment.

ECR partially accepts the issue’s cohesion policy framework but demands explicit retention of GDP-based regional eligibility criteria to prevent arbitrary fund allocation.  
ECR objects to reduced financing for remote regions, insisting the issue must prioritize geographic balance over efficiency-driven cuts.  
ECR requests amendments to explicitly designate north-south infrastructural corridors in Western Europe as critical investments under territorial pacts.  
ECR supports higher co-financing rates but requires safeguards against diverting resources from less developed regions in Central/Southern Europe.  
ECR emphasizes that measurable result indicators must directly address growth disparities between "old" and "new" EU member states.

GUE_NGL supports the issue's emphasis on territorial cohesion but advises increasing the budgetary allocation to cohesion funds beyond current proposals to address deepening regional inequalities.  
GUE_NGL recommends amending Clause 9 to explicitly prioritize public-sector investments in health, education, and earthquake protection over public-private partnerships that prioritize capital returns.  
GUE_NGL expresses concern that the issue insufficiently challenges EU macro-economic policies exacerbating poverty through salary cuts and privatization, urging binding links between cohesion funding and social rights protections.  
GUE_NGL advises incorporating measurable indicators for social cohesion in Article 6, including poverty reduction targets and minimum service accessibility standards aligned with sustainable development goals.  
GUE_NGL calls for deletion of references to "market liberalization competitiveness" in Annex 3, proposing replacement language emphasizing job creation through localized green industrial strategies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to strengthen multi-level governance and partnership in EU cohesion policy, emphasizing coordinated action among EU, national, regional, and local authorities, socio-economic partners, and NGOs to enhance legitimacy, transparency, and fund absorption. It highlighted systemic weaknesses in control mechanisms, citing a 12% error rate in 2006 and 11% in 2008 for unduly reimbursed cohesion funds, urging the Commission to improve audit systems, reduce administrative burdens, and prioritize result-oriented policies with measurable indicators. The resolution called for compulsory application of multi-level governance in EU policies with territorial impact, including integrated approaches addressing economic, social, and environmental challenges, tailored to regional specificities. It advocated for stronger regional involvement in program design, implementation, and decision-making, alongside simplified funding rules, harmonized Structural Funds, and wider use of lump-sum payments to boost efficiency. Administrative capacity-building at all levels, including training initiatives like an "Erasmus for elected local representatives," and enhanced public consultation were stressed. The Parliament urged maintaining cohesion policy funding post-2013, rejecting renationalization, and demanded timely Commission proposals for the next programming period to avoid delays. It endorsed territorial pacts, a European multi-level governance label, and improved coordination within the Commission to ensure coherence, while promoting transparency, flexible crisis responses, and trust-based partnerships with Member States demonstrating effective fund use.

title: Regional strategies for industrial areas in the European Union: REPORT on regional strategies for industrial areas in the European Union
background: The European Union’s emphasis on economic cohesion, industrial competitiveness via structural funds, and challenges in adapting industrial regions to environmental and economic transitions prompted attention. The Parliament will discuss regional strategies for industrial areas to address structural economic shifts and cohesion policy alignment.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the strategic use of EU structural funds for industrial revitalization, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to regional economic resilience and sustainable job creation.  
EPP approves the issue’s focus on sustainable production and energy-efficient technologies, which effectively advances their priority of decarbonizing industry while maintaining competitiveness.  
EPP endorses the integration of gender and age considerations in regional strategies, reflecting their comprehensive approach to inclusive growth and social cohesion in industrial transitions.  
EPP emphasizes the critical role of cultural industries and high-value craftsmanship in territorial reconversion, urging their explicit inclusion as innovative sectors under the issue’s investment priorities.  
EPP proposes strengthening rural-urban synergies by linking industrial modernization with agricultural supply chains and vocational training systems, ensuring a holistic regional development framework.

EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on energy-efficient renovations but advises amending funding criteria to prioritize modernization of existing industrial assets like Prato’s textile districts rather than solely funding replacement sectors.  
EFD endorses job creation through sustainable production yet proposes modifying Article 7 to include heritage status protections for legacy manufacturing ecosystems with proven technical expertise.  
EFD agrees with leveraging structural funds for green transitions but urges explicit Cohesion Fund allocations to defend regionally vital industries such as Piombino’s steelworks from disproportionate phase-out pressures.  
EFD concurs with reducing industrial footprints through smart transport solutions while emphasizing the need to retain core production capacities through updated emissions-reduction technologies.  
EFD cautions against overreliance on cultural industries to replace traditional sectors, advocating balanced regional strategies that preserve historical supply chains alongside innovation investments.

ALDE strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on regional coordination with municipalities, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to decentralized governance and local economic empowerment.  
ALDE highlights the success of Bilbao’s transformation as a model for sustainable industrial renewal, demonstrating how regional strategies can drive innovation and citizen engagement.  
ALDE urges enhanced institutional recognition of regional identities in EU policy frameworks to maximize structural fund efficiency and grassroots development.  
ALDE proposes strengthening multi-level governance mechanisms to ensure regional expertise directly shapes industrial modernization and green investment priorities.  
ALDE approves the focus on public-private synergies for eco-innovation, noting its alignment with job creation and climate resilience goals in regional industrial strategies.

SD strongly advocates the integration of EU structural funds to drive sustainable industrial transformation, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to regional job creation and decarbonization through energy-efficient renovations.  
SD applauds the issue's emphasis on public-private synergies in eco-innovation, which effectively advances SD's priority of transitioning industrial regions to high-value green technologies.  
SD proposes enhancing fund allocation oversight to ensure strict alignment with inclusive reindustrialization goals, addressing concerns about misdirected investments in non-sustainable sectors.  
SD endorses the call for gender- and age-sensitive regional strategies, recognizing this as critical to maximizing workforce potential in line with SD's social equity principles.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of modernizing legacy industrial zones through smart transport solutions and repurposing port areas, a key opportunity to reduce environmental footprints without public debt burdens.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of leveraging EU structural funds, including the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and Cohesion Fund, to advance renewable energy, energy efficiency, and sustainable production and consumption patterns. It emphasized energy-efficient building renovations as a means to reduce carbon emissions, create local jobs, and lower heating costs for consumers. The resolution called for synergies between public and private investments in eco-innovation, environmental technologies, and renewable energy to generate high-value jobs and address societal challenges, while stressing the need for budget-neutral restructuring of industrial areas using existing funds. It urged the continuation of state aid for large firms in sustainable industries under the 2014-2020 regional guidelines and highlighted the role of regional strategies in integrating gender and age considerations to avoid missed opportunities. Environmental protection measures, including alignment with the Waste, Water, and Air Quality Directives, were underscored, alongside sustainable transport solutions like waterways, rail networks, and smart distribution to reduce industrial footprints. The resolution advocated strict implementation of the Seveso III Directive to mitigate risks for citizens near industrial zones and promoted public participation in land-use planning. It noted the potential of modernizing outdated industrial areas with energy-efficient technologies and repurposing former industrial sites, such as port areas, to fund green investments and reduce reliance on public financing.

title: Territorial, social and economic cohesion: REPORT on achieving real territorial, social and economic cohesion within the EU – a sine qua non for global competitiveness?
background: Persistent regional economic disparities, global competition pressures, and challenges from demographic shifts, climate change, and infrastructure gaps prompted EU institutional focus on cohesion policies. The Parliament will discuss whether territorial, social, and economic cohesion is indispensable for enhancing the EU's global competitiveness through coordinated regional development strategies and funding frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on multi-level governance and bottom-up approaches, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to subsidiarity and regional empowerment in cohesion policy implementation.  
EPP approves maintaining GDP as the primary eligibility criterion while advocating enhanced regional management roles to address specific territorial challenges like depopulation, consistent with EPP's territorial justice principles.  
EPP proposes simplifying fund access procedures and strengthening audit mechanisms to reduce error rates, enhancing cohesion policy's effectiveness without opposing its core architecture.  
EPP applauds the focus on cross-border cooperation and urban-rural integration as critical drivers of EU competitiveness, matching EPP's 2023 priorities for interconnected regional economies.  
EPP endorses decentralized fund management models that leverage regional expertise, noting this directly advances the Treaty of Lisbon's governance objectives as championed by EPP members.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the issue’s prioritization of GDP-driven growth metrics and infrastructure-centric cohesion, which neglects ecological transformation as a core competitiveness strategy.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the failure to mandate green economy transitions in cohesion funding, contradicting their manifesto’s call for a binding "Green New Deal" to replace extractive growth models.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s inconsistency with biodiversity safeguards, as it omits explicit criteria to align R&D investments with nature restoration or circular economy principles.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the inadequate emphasis on civil society partnerships in governance, undermining grassroots-led territorial development central to Green/EFA’s multi-level democracy ethos.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the proposal’s incompatibility with climate resilience goals by permitting remoteness or depopulation to remain secondary to GDP in fund allocation.

SD strongly advocates maintaining or increasing cohesion policy funding to ensure equitable development and regional ownership, aligning with their commitment to reducing disparities and advancing sustainable growth.  
SD approves enhancing multi-level governance and technical assistance for local authorities, crucial for effective fund management and aligning with SD’s focus on participatory governance and simplified access to resources.  
SD advocates against punitive conditionality that penalizes regions for national government shortcomings, proposing collaborative frameworks to protect regional autonomy while ensuring accountability.  
SD emphasizes the need for streamlined Structural Fund rules and reinforced oversight mechanisms to reduce administrative burdens, enhance transparency, and address ineligible expenditure risks.  
SD highlights public-private partnerships and infrastructure investment as essential to cohesion policy, strongly endorsing their role in achieving EU 2020 goals and global competitiveness.

GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the issue's emphasis on capitalist competitiveness, which entrenches systemic inequalities inherent to EU economic policies.  
GUE/NGL rejects the allocation of cohesion funds to public-private partnerships, arguing these prioritize capital returns over grassroots social needs like healthcare and education.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's alignment with the EU 2020 strategy, viewing it as a vehicle for anti-worker restructuring and erosion of social rights.  
GUE/NGL disputes the adequacy of GDP-based funding criteria, citing Latvia's poverty rates as proof of the policy's failure to address real territorial disparities.  
GUE/NGL asserts that leaving the EU and pursuing socialist planned economies are necessary to achieve genuine cohesion, contrary to the issue’s market-driven framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of cohesion policy in reducing regional disparities, enhancing global competitiveness, and achieving EU 2020 strategy goals, emphasizing its necessity for sustainable, low-carbon economic growth and resilience against crises. It highlighted that €86 billion was allocated to R&D and innovation for 2007-2013, with €50 billion dedicated to core activities, stressing continued investment in these areas alongside infrastructure, education, and workforce development to address global challenges. The resolution underscored the interdependence of competitiveness and cohesion, advocating for a place-based approach to leverage regional strengths, address territorial disparities, and promote multi-level governance, with only 30.5% of cohesion funds currently managed by regions. It called for strengthened partnerships, simplified fund access for SMEs, and enhanced public-private collaborations, while maintaining GDP as the primary criterion for funding eligibility alongside region-specific factors like remoteness or depopulation. The Parliament urged alignment of cohesion policy with EU 2020 priorities—smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth—while preserving its independence to address regional needs, and stressed the importance of cross-border cooperation, urban-rural integration, and gender equality in driving economic growth. It advocated maintaining or increasing the cohesion budget post-2013 to ensure equitable development, support lagging regions, and consolidate progress in key sectors like energy, transport, and digital innovation, ensuring accessibility and social inclusion across all EU territories.

title: Smart specialisation: networking excellence for a sound Cohesion Policy: REPORT on smart specialisation: networking excellence for a sound Cohesion Policy
background: The European Union’s post-2013 Cohesion Policy reforms, aligned with Europe 2020 goals, emphasized regional innovation strategies, supported by Commission proposals (2011), OECD analysis (2012), and RIS3 guidelines. The Parliament will discuss integrating smart specialisation into cohesion frameworks to enhance regional competitiveness and research-driven growth.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the regional smart specialization strategies as a catalyst for innovation-driven growth, aligning perfectly with their commitment to cohesion policy and Europe 2020 objectives.  
EPP approves the emphasis on ex-ante conditionalities to ensure strategic alignment with EU priorities, effectively advancing competitiveness through ERDF and ESF synergies.  
EPP proposes strengthening monitoring frameworks to safeguard R&D investment levels, ensuring the 3% GDP target remains a binding benchmark for member states.  
EPP endorses cross-border knowledge transfer initiatives as critical for territorial cohesion, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for reducing regional disparities through collaborative ecosystems.  
EPP emphasizes democratic stakeholder engagement in strategy design, ensuring local authorities, academia, and businesses jointly define comparative advantages.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue's emphasis on cross-regional cooperation and innovation ecosystems, aligning perfectly with their commitment to reducing disparities through collaborative knowledge transfer.  
GREEN_EFA approves the integration of territorial cohesion in external cooperation, effectively advancing their priority of inclusive growth across EU regions.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing the Sevilla platform's accessibility to ensure all regions can actively contribute to smart specialization strategies, strengthening the issue's participatory framework.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on measurable innovation outputs, which matches their manifesto goals for transparent and accountable regional development policies.  
GREEN_EFA recommends explicitly prioritizing youth engagement in RIS3 implementation to bridge future innovation needs, building on the issue's support for next-generation researchers.

SD strongly agrees the emphasis on cross-border smart specialisation strategies, aligning with SD's longstanding commitment to territorial cohesion through shared innovation ecosystems and stakeholder collaboration.  
SD approves the mandatory integration of research and innovation strategies for 2014-2020, proposing enhanced DG-led training to ensure regions maximize structural fund synergies as a minor operational refinement.  
SD emphasizes the critical need for sustained R&D investment to match smart specialisation goals, urging member states to avoid funding cuts that undermine regional competitiveness and SD’s priority of reducing disparities.  
SD applauds the focus on innovation incubators and creative industry linkages as a direct advancement of SD’s manifesto goals for inclusive, knowledge-driven growth.  
SD highlights cross-regional knowledge transfer as pivotal to reducing inequalities, urging stricter ex-ante conditionalities to ensure private sector engagement aligns with EU-wide priorities.

ECR supports the principle of regional empowerment in smart specialisation strategies but advises enhancing administrative capacity-building programs to ensure effective fund utilization.  
ECR proposes amending ex-ante conditionalities to include mandatory assessments of regional implementation capabilities before allocating structural funds.  
ECR highlights concerns about overburdening regions with complex socio-economic challenges, urging phased capacity development aligned with national competency frameworks.  
ECR recommends strengthening central-level technical assistance mechanisms to support regions in accessing and managing cohesion policy instruments efficiently.  
ECR emphasizes the need for clear metrics tracking both innovation outputs and administrative efficiency gains to validate cohesion policy effectiveness.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance cohesion policy post-2013 by aligning it with the Europe 2020 Strategy’s objectives for smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth, emphasizing innovation-driven regional development through smart specialization strategies (RIS3). It stressed the importance of synergies between the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), European Social Fund, and other structural funds to maximize efficiency, avoid duplication, and support cross-regional cooperation. The resolution highlighted the role of regions in fostering innovation ecosystems through closer collaboration with businesses, universities, and research institutions, while advocating for stronger ex-ante conditionalities to ensure strategic alignment with EU priorities. It called for integrating territorial cohesion into external cooperation to address disparities and promote knowledge transfer, particularly in cross-border initiatives. The Parliament underscored the need for measurable innovation outputs and urged coherence between regional policies and broader EU frameworks, such as the Innovation Union and Research and Development programs, to strengthen competitiveness and reduce economic, social, and territorial inequalities.

title: Risk sharing instruments for Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1083/2006 as regards certain provisions relating to risk-sharing instruments for Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability
background: Following the 2008 financial crisis and subsequent sovereign debt challenges, several EU Member States faced severe financial instability, impacting cohesion policy implementation due to constrained private investment and banking sector liquidity issues. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to establish risk-sharing instruments enabling access to finance for infrastructure and productive investments in affected states.

stances.stance:

title: Role of EU cohesion policy in implementing the new European energy policy: REPORT on the role of EU cohesion policy and its actors in implementing the new European energy policy
background: The European Union established energy policy objectives (security, sustainability, competitiveness) through treaties and strategic frameworks (Energy 2020, Energy Roadmap 2050), while cohesion policy prioritized regional development via Structural Funds. Rising energy costs, infrastructure disparities, and alignment challenges between energy transition goals and regional investment mechanisms created operational tensions. The Parliament will discuss integrating cohesion policy instruments with EU energy priorities to address territorial disparities and market integration.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to align cohesion policy with EU energy objectives under the Europe 2020 strategy, emphasizing investments in energy efficiency, renewable energy, and low-carbon infrastructure to achieve smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth. It stressed that cohesion funds, including the Structural Funds and Cohesion Fund, should prioritize projects contributing to regional development, job creation, and energy poverty reduction, particularly in less-developed regions, while ensuring 20% of funding for energy efficiency and 6% for renewables. The resolution highlighted the importance of simplifying access to these funds, reducing bureaucratic barriers, and enhancing administrative capacity to improve absorption rates, especially for small communities and rural areas facing challenges with large funding thresholds (e.g., ELENA’s €50 million minimum). It advocated for flexible, region-specific energy strategies, cross-border cooperation, and smart grids to integrate renewable sources and eliminate energy isolation by 2015. The Parliament called for leveraging financial instruments like JESSICA and the Connecting Europe Facility to modernize energy infrastructure, support Smart Cities initiatives, and promote synergies between public and private funding. It underscored the role of cohesion policy in transitioning fossil fuel-dependent regions to sustainable energy, addressing energy price impacts on vulnerable households, and balancing climate goals with regional competitiveness. Additionally, the resolution urged VAT reductions for energy-efficient projects, prioritized local renewable distribution over large-scale transmission, and emphasized the need for rural-focused energy strategies, including microgeneration and LPG/LNG alternatives in off-grid areas. Achieving the 20% energy efficiency target by 2020 was deemed critical to reducing fossil fuel imports by 25%, with cohesion funds playing a pivotal role in building renovations, public transport, and district heating upgrades.

title: Role of territorial development in cohesion policy: REPORT on optimising the role of territorial development in cohesion policy
background: The Lisbon Treaty established territorial cohesion as a core EU objective, with cohesion policy historically targeting regional disparities through structural funds. Proposed 2014-2020 regulatory frameworks sought improved coordination across EU funding instruments and integration of territorial strategies into regional development. The Parliament will discuss optimizing territorial development's role in cohesion policy to address regional challenges and EU-wide cohesion goals.

GUE/NGL highlights the proposal’s failure to acknowledge systemic flaws, noting that reduced budgets and fragmented funding mechanisms deepen divergence rather than cohesion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of cohesion policy in reducing economic, social, and territorial disparities across EU regions, advocating for maintaining its post-2013 budget at current levels to sustain support for disadvantaged areas. It emphasized a multi-level governance approach, requiring collaboration across European, national, regional, and local levels in planning and implementing funding programs, alongside simplified administrative procedures and results-driven flexibility to enhance effectiveness. The resolution endorsed integrating funds (ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund, EARDF, EMFF) through mechanisms like community-led local development (CLLD), integrated territorial investments (ITIs), and joint action plans, highlighting examples such as Wales’ single funding portal and Greater Manchester’s cross-fund ITI model. It stressed aligning cohesion policy with Europe 2020 goals, particularly employment, education, and poverty reduction, while fostering synergies with Horizon 2020 and LIFE+ for innovation and research. The Parliament underscored the importance of territorial cohesion, supporting urban-rural linkages, SMEs, vocational training, and addressing challenges in cross-border, mountain, island, and outermost regions. It advocated leveraging financial instruments to attract private investment, improving healthcare access via broadband and telemedicine, and combating youth unemployment and social exclusion through targeted, region-specific strategies. The resolution also called for balanced checks on fund use, stakeholder involvement, and capacity-building to ensure cohesive, sustainable development across all EU territories.

title: Urban redevelopment as contribution to economic growth: REPORT on urban re-development as contribution to economic growth in the framework of the EU Cohesion Policy

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns that 80% of EU citizens live in urban areas facing intensified challenges from climate change, economic crises, social exclusion, and environmental pollution, urging integrated, sustainable urban development. It stressed the need for medium-to-long-term action plans to enhance economic, social, and territorial cohesion, regenerate marginalized neighborhoods, repurpose disused spaces, and preserve cultural heritage while promoting social inclusion and citizen participation. The resolution called for allocating at least 5% of European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) resources to sustainable urban development managed by cities, emphasizing energy-efficient housing, green spaces, sustainable mobility, and resilience against natural disasters. It highlighted the role of urban areas in achieving Europe 2020 goals, advocating integrated approaches linking environmental, cultural, and economic priorities, and fostering urban-rural synergies to prevent spatial segregation. The Parliament urged leveraging Horizon 2020 and Covenant of Mayors initiatives for innovation, improved multilevel governance, and technical assistance to local authorities for effective fund management. It prioritized combating energy inefficiency, waste management, water quality, and addressing inequalities through housing policies and service accessibility, while warning against gentrification risks and advocating inclusive planning to protect vulnerable groups.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key priorities regarding the EU’s cohesion policy and its alignment with the Europe 2020 strategy, emphasizing its role as the Union’s primary investment tool with a budget of €351.8 billion until 2020 to reduce regional disparities, promote sustainable growth, and address crises like high unemployment and uneven economic recovery. It stressed the need for stronger multi-level governance, territorial cohesion, and synergies between cohesion policy and other EU initiatives, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which aims to mobilize €315 billion for strategic projects, while ensuring complementarity with European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds). The resolution highlighted delays in implementing the 2014-2020 cohesion programmes, despite increased allocations for R&D, SMEs, climate action, and social inclusion, and called for improved coordination with the Europe 2020 strategy’s objectives—employment, innovation, climate sustainability, education, and poverty reduction—through enhanced governance, performance frameworks, and ex-ante conditionalities linked to country-specific recommendations. It urged a territorial approach to address diverse regional needs, including rural, cross-border, and outermost regions, and emphasized the role of cities and macro-regional strategies in driving growth. The Parliament advocated for a mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy to strengthen ownership by local and regional actors, improve result-oriented indicators beyond GDP, and integrate gender equality and social inclusion, while avoiding disruptive reprogramming of cohesion policy. It also highlighted the importance of Horizon 2020 synergies, administrative capacity-building, and future cohesion policy post-2020, stressing the need for sustained funding and coherence with the EU’s long-term strategic goals.

title: Cohesion policy and the circular economy: REPORT on cohesion policy and the circular economy

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of cohesion policy in advancing the circular economy, emphasizing the need to align post-2020 funding with EU climate and sustainability goals. It highlighted that cities, responsible for 75% of global resource consumption and 60-80% of greenhouse gas emissions, require targeted investments in waste reduction, recycling infrastructure, and renewable energy to meet 2030 and 2035 EU waste targets. Noting that 60% of EU waste remains unrecycled, the resolution urged leveraging €150 billion in 2014-2020 EU funds for circular economy projects, alongside €2.4 billion in EIB financing for waste, water, and agricultural R&D. It called for improved tracking methodologies to monitor cohesion policy’s contribution to circularity, stricter adherence to the waste hierarchy (prioritizing prevention, reuse, and recycling over incineration), and enhanced regional cooperation to address challenges like China’s scrap import ban and marine litter (80% of which originates on land). The Parliament stressed integrating circular economy principles into education, vocational training, and smart specialization strategies, while boosting Green Public Procurement (€1.8 trillion annual potential) and supporting SMEs through platforms like the Circular Economy Finance Support Platform. It advocated for binding ex-ante conditionalities in future cohesion policy to ensure compliance with circular economy goals, increased climate-related spending, and synergies between Horizon 2020, LIFE, and ESI Funds. The resolution also emphasized remediating illegal landfills, promoting bioeconomy innovations to reduce CO2 emissions by 2.5 billion tonnes annually by 2030, and revising policies to incentivize recycled materials over raw resources, including EU-level taxation and single-use plastic regulations.

title: Cohesion policy and thematic objective ‘promoting sustainable transport and removing bottlenecks in key network infrastructures’: REPORT on the implementation of cohesion policy and the thematic objective of ‘promoting sustainable transport and removing bottlenecks in key network infrastructures’ - Article 9(7) of the Common Provisions Regulation

GUE_NGL completely rejects with the issue's market-driven infrastructure expansion model, which perpetuates urban-rural divides rather than decentralizing economic activity to reduce transport demands.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's inconsistency with climate justice by neglecting binding requirements to reactivate abandoned rail lines for sustainable passenger/freight mobility instead of road-centric investments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of EU cohesion policy and sustainable transport investments in fostering economic growth, reducing regional disparities, and advancing climate goals. It emphasized maintaining the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF), Cohesion Fund (CF), and European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) as core funding sources for transport infrastructure, with €81 billion (31% of ESI Funds) allocated to transport in 2007-2013 and €24 billion via CEF for 2014-2020, prioritizing rail and TEN-T core networks. The resolution highlighted the need for balanced, spillover-effective investments across all regions, particularly lagging, mountainous, remote, and outermost areas, to address bottlenecks, multimodal connectivity, and decarbonization through shifts to rail, waterways, and electric vehicles. It called for integrating climate objectives into transport projects, enforcing environmental legislation (e.g., Natura 2000, air quality directives), and aligning funding with EU decarbonization targets. Cross-border infrastructure, including with the Western Balkans, was stressed, alongside simplified funding procedures, blended financing (e.g., EFSI, PPPs), and technical assistance to enhance project implementation. The Parliament urged strengthening urban mobility, intelligent transport systems, cycling infrastructure (e.g., EuroVelo), and accessibility for persons with disabilities, while maintaining grants as the primary tool for public transport. It advocated for harmonized transport strategies post-2020, increased DG MOVE involvement, and adherence to the "use it or lose it" principle to ensure timely project execution. Road safety initiatives, user-pays principles for green logistics, and equitable resource allocation to close infrastructure gaps between Member States were also underscored.

title: Boosting growth and cohesion in EU border regions: REPORT on boosting growth and cohesion in EU border regions
background: EU border regions, covering 40% of EU territory and 30% of its population, face persistent administrative, legal, and linguistic barriers hindering economic development and cross-border cooperation, as identified in a 2017 Commission analysis. The Parliament will discuss strategies to enhance cross-border integration and address disparities to unlock regional potential.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the issue's focus on cross-border worker mobility, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to eliminating barriers to free movement and labor market integration.  
EPP approves the emphasis on transport connectivity enhancements, particularly completing missing infrastructure links, which effectively advances EPP's priority of creating seamless trans-European networks.  
EPP endorses the creation of joint digital portals for cross-border entrepreneurship, matching EPP's manifesto goals to empower SMEs through digital single market tools.  
EPP highlights the need to strengthen regional authorities' implementation capacity through increased Interreg funding simplification, proposing clearer guidelines for local administrations to access EU cooperation instruments.  
EPP applauds the territorial cooperation programs as critical mechanisms to reduce disparities, a principle central to EPP's cohesion policy agenda since 2014.

EFDD partly advocates infrastructure investments but demands amendments to remove binding EU legal harmonization clauses, prioritizing national sovereignty.  
EFDD opposes the European cross-border convention as centralizing governance, advocating instead for bilateral agreements under subsidiarity principles.  
EFDD rejects expanded Interreg funding post-2020, insisting allocations be decided by member states without Brussels-led territorial assessments.  
EFDD highlights the issue’s failure to address Brexit’s democratic mandate, urging deletion of cohesion policy references to the UK’s withdrawal.  
EFDD requests revising SME support mechanisms to exclude EU-level regulatory oversight, emphasizing national control over labor mobility frameworks.

SD fundamentally sanctions the issue’s emphasis on simplifying cross-border employment procedures and enhancing labor mobility, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to dismantling administrative barriers for SMEs and job creation.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call to expand post-2020 funding for Interreg and ETC programs, recognizing their indispensable role in fostering economic cohesion and infrastructure development in border regions.  
SD fully supports the prioritization of Schengen integration for Romania and Bulgaria, viewing it as a critical step to eliminate internal border disparities and strengthen the single market’s integrity.  
SD endorses preserving maritime cross-border cooperation frameworks, advocating for tailored strategies that protect successful models like Baltic Sea transport networks and youth cultural exchanges.  
SD advocates leveraging cohesion policy to harmonize qualifications recognition and cross-border healthcare access, advancing social integration and equitable growth across all EU territories.

ECR strongly promotes the issue’s focus on dismantling administrative barriers to cross-border SME growth, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to fostering competitive markets and reducing bureaucratic overreach.  
ECR applauds the emphasis on sustainable transport infrastructure through dedicated CEF budgets, which effectively advances ECR’s priority of strategic connectivity without expanding EU regulatory frameworks.  
ECR proposes amending the cohesion policy provisions to explicitly reference bilateral agreements as complementary tools to Interreg programs, ensuring respect for national competencies in post-Brexit cooperation.  
ECR approves the call for harmonizing legal frameworks for cross-border workers, urging enhanced wording to safeguard member states’ autonomy in labor market regulations.  
ECR endorses the issue’s recognition of multilingual education and cultural initiatives as drivers of integration, reflecting ECR’s advocacy for subsidiarity in community-led cohesion efforts.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about persistent challenges in EU border regions, which cover 40% of EU territory, host 30% of its population, and contribute nearly a third of EU GDP, yet face socio-economic disparities, administrative barriers, and underdeveloped infrastructure. It highlighted that removing 20% of existing obstacles could boost GDP by 2% (€91 billion) and create 1 million jobs, emphasizing the need to address legal, linguistic, and regulatory barriers hindering cross-border healthcare, labor mobility (noting 2 million cross-border workers and students), SME growth (SMEs employ 67% of workers and generate 57% of value added), and transport connectivity, including missing railway links. The resolution urged enhanced use of EU tools like European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) and Interreg programs, calling for increased post-2020 funding, simplified procedures, and dedicated CEF budgets for sustainable transport. It stressed multilingual education, mutual recognition of qualifications, e-government interoperability, and cross-border cultural initiatives to foster integration, while advocating tailored approaches for maritime and external borders, including support for outermost regions. The Parliament also emphasized cohesion policy’s role in addressing Brexit impacts, promoting macro-regional strategies, and leveraging cultural and creative industries (CCIs) to drive growth, social cohesion, and tourism. It urged Member States to harmonize legal frameworks, improve emergency services cooperation, and expand cross-border healthcare zones (e.g., ZOAST areas), while highlighting the need for youth engagement, apprenticeships, and measures to combat discrimination and support vulnerable groups. Finally, it called for a European cross-border convention to resolve legal obstacles and enhance territorial impact assessments in EU legislation.

title: Building blocks for a post-2020 EU cohesion policy: REPORT on building blocks for a post-2020 EU cohesion policy
background: The EU's 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework neared its conclusion, requiring evaluation of cohesion policy's role in addressing regional disparities, economic recovery, and structural challenges like migration, climate change, and Brexit's budgetary implications. The Parliament will discuss post-2020 cohesion policy reforms, funding priorities, and alignment with EU strategic goals.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the integration of migration funding into cohesion policy, completely disputeing with their stance that EU funds must prioritize citizens facing poverty over migrant support.  
ENF opposes replacing GDP-based allocation metrics, declaring the issue’s supplementary indicators inconsistent with their demand for objective economic prioritization.  
ENF condemns the issue’s trust in EU financial management, citing the Spaak building’s €340M waste as proof of systemic incompetence in fund oversight.  
ENF demands cohesion policy reforms to eliminate fraud, highlighting OLAF’s €631M findings as evidence current anti-corruption measures are insufficient.  
ENF opposes administrative flexibility clauses, warning they could create bureaucratic burdens contrary to ENF’s push for deregulated, nationally tailored implementation.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds maintaining cohesion policy as the cornerstone of European solidarity, aligning perfectly with their commitment to reducing regional disparities through sustainable investments in renewable energy and social infrastructure.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing anti-corruption safeguards by amending funding rules to require full participation in the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) as a precondition for accessing cohesion funds, thereby strengthening accountability mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s climate action targets and 20% budget allocation as effectively advancing their manifesto priorities for a green economic transition, particularly through local energy communities and Just Transition mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the emphasis on urban development and Integrated Territorial Investments to address migration integration, urging explicit inclusion of climate asylum frameworks in future operational programs.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to eliminate macroeconomic conditionality clauses that disproportionately penalize vulnerable communities, proposing instead performance indicators focused on social equity and decarbonization progress.

ALDE rejects the issue's approach to maintaining cohesion funding levels post-Brexit, absolutely disputeing with their insistence on stricter macroeconomic conditionalities tied to structural reforms.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding linkages between cohesion funds and country-specific reform agendas, a core ALDE requirement for fiscal accountability.  
ALDE opposes the issue's insufficient emphasis on streamlining state aid rules and audit processes, which contradicts their demand for radical simplification to enhance policy efficiency.  
The urban dimension and Interreg provisions fail to address ALDE's priority of mandating performance-based allocation to ensure funds directly target growth-oriented regions.  
By not requiring explicit alignment with Stability Pact compliance, the issue undermines ALDE's principle that cohesion investments must reinforce, not circumvent, economic governance frameworks.

SD fully advocates the issue's insistence on maintaining cohesion policy funding at current levels, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to EU solidarity and addressing regional disparities through structural investments.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for enhanced communication strategies to demonstrate cohesion policy's tangible impacts, mirroring SD's emphasis on citizen engagement and countering populist narratives against EU value visibility.  
SD fully advocates the prioritization of SMEs and territorial cooperation tools like ITI, which directly advance SD's manifesto goals of job creation and inclusive growth across all regions.  
SD perfectly supports integrating climate action with 20% budget allocation, reflecting SD's climate justice agenda and demand for synergies between cohesion funds and Horizon 2020 sustainability projects.  
SD fully advocates abolishing macroeconomic conditionality clauses in cohesion spending, aligning with SD's opposition to austerity-driven policies that undermine social convergence targets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the necessity of maintaining a robust, adequately funded cohesion policy post-2020 to address regional disparities, foster economic and social convergence, and uphold EU solidarity. It emphasized cohesion policy’s role as the EU’s primary investment tool for sustainable growth, job creation, and climate action, advocating for its budget share to remain at least equivalent to current levels despite challenges like Brexit. Key priorities included simplifying administrative procedures, enhancing flexibility through mechanisms like a reserve for unforeseen events, and accelerating implementation by reducing bureaucratic burdens and leveraging digital tools. The resolution stressed the importance of territorial cooperation (Interreg), macro-regional strategies, and support for outermost regions, while calling for increased funding for European Territorial Cooperation (ETC) to address cross-border challenges. It highlighted the need to integrate climate objectives, including dedicating 20% of the EU budget to climate-related actions, and improving synergies between cohesion funds, Horizon 2020, and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) without undermining grants. The Parliament advocated for maintaining the seven-year programming period (or a 5+5 model with midterm review), performance-based allocation, and supplementary indicators beyond GDP—such as social progress or demographics—to better capture regional inequalities. It underscored the urban dimension, SMEs (responsible for 80% of EU jobs), and tools like Integrated Territorial Investments (ITI) to address challenges like migration integration, demographic shifts, and digital transformation. Lastly, the resolution urged stronger multi-level governance, streamlined state aid rules, balanced use of financial instruments, and enhanced communication to improve policy visibility and citizen engagement.

title: Acceleration of implementation of cohesion policy: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on acceleration of implementation of cohesion policy
background: Delays in implementing the 2014-2020 EU cohesion policy, including late operational program approvals, unmet ex-ante conditionalities, and risks of financial decommitment under regulatory deadlines, prompted concerns over fund utilization. The Parliament will discuss measures to accelerate cohesion policy execution while addressing administrative and structural challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly supports the issue's emphasis on simplified procedures and administrative capacity building, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to efficient fund absorption and structural reform.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for integrated territorial strategies, particularly in mountainous regions, advancing EPP's priority of balanced regional development through synergies between agriculture, tourism, and environmental protection.  
EPP firmly supports leveraging ESI Funds with EFSI to maximize private investment, reflecting EPP's manifesto goals for job creation and competitiveness in cohesion regions.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand for early post-2020 planning, reinforcing EPP's longstanding focus on policy stability and reduced implementation delays.  
EPP firmly supports enhanced communication measures to increase public awareness of cohesion benefits, mirroring EPP's emphasis on tangible EU visibility in local projects.

EFDD rejects the issue's reliance on financial instruments like EFSI, which Isabella Adinolfi criticizes as unproven "financial engineering" that fails to address geographic disadvantages in mountainous regions.  
EFDD fully againsts cohesion policy's linkage to EU governance conditions, with Rosa D'Amato condemning structural fund ties to economic reforms as "absolutely inconceivable" and incompatible with local participation.  
EFDD opposes integrated territorial investments as federalist overreach, with Julia Reid denouncing them as political tools to erode national identities under false economic pretenses.  
EFDD rejects redistribution mechanisms that Bill Etheridge argues penalize poorer UK regions, calling cohesion funds a "shameful" diversion of resources from domestic healthcare and schools to EU priorities.  
EFDD condemns mandatory EU propaganda signage referenced by Julia Reid as deceptive branding of reclaimed taxpayer funds, fully doubting with transparency claims in the issue.

ENF fundamentally rejects the cohesion policy's premise of EU unity as contradictory to their core belief that "Europe has become an incontinent continent" through EU-induced disintegration.  
ENF opposes ESI Fund allocations as perpetuating wealth extraction from impoverished regions like South Wales to fund "everywhere in the world" against local needs (Resolution §1, §14).  
ENF condemns agricultural standardization attempts under cohesion policy as destructive to mountain communities' sovereignty, citing Loiseau's Alpine example of "28% farm loss" from EU-driven concentration (Resolution §5, §9).  
ENF declares the issue's EU governance tools like Integrated Territorial Investment incompatible with their demand for "collaborations between sovereign states" rather than federalist overreach (Resolution §8).  
ENF argues the issue's focus on gender equality in mountain regions (§49) exemplifies ideological overreach that "destroys nations" by ignoring territorial specificities (Loiseau debate point).

ALDE fundamentally accepts the issue's emphasis on subsidiarity and decentralized governance as critical to empowering mountain communities and local action groups.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's call for simplified procedures and streamlined access to ESI Funds to accelerate territorial development through LAG-led initiatives.  
ALDE fundamentally accepts the integration of ITI and CLLD instruments as essential tools to operationalize subsidiarity principles in line with ALDE's localism agenda.  
ALDE perfectly supports the issue's demand for administrative capacity building to eliminate bottlenecks hindering cohesion policy's transformative potential.  
ALDE fundamentally accepts combining ESI Funds with EFSI to amplify private investments in marginalized regions, reflecting ALDE's innovation-driven growth model.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over delays and challenges in implementing the 2014-2020 Cohesion Policy, which allocates over €350 billion through European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds to reduce regional disparities, boost competitiveness, and advance Europe 2020 goals. It emphasized the need to address risks of decommitment under Article 136(1) of the Common Provisions Regulation, urging the Commission to analyze payment forecasts and propose measures to prevent fund losses. The resolution highlighted persistent obstacles from the 2007-2013 period, including complex procurement, state aid rules, and administrative bottlenecks, and called for simplified procedures, strengthened administrative capacity, and better use of financial instruments to leverage private investment. It stressed the importance of fulfilling ex-ante conditionalities by 2016 to avoid payment suspensions and urged alignment with EU priorities like the Energy Union and digital single market. The Parliament welcomed the Commission’s Task Force for Better Implementation in eight Member States but demanded accelerated action and transparency. It advocated combining ESI Funds with the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) to enhance impact, urged flexibility under the Stability and Growth Pact to address liquidity shortages, and highlighted the need for decentralized governance through tools like Integrated Territorial Investment. The resolution also called for improved communication to raise public awareness of Cohesion Policy’s benefits and urged early planning for post-2020 reforms to enhance efficiency and targeting.

title: Common provisions on European Structural and Investment Funds: specific measures for Greece: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and laying down general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund as regards specific measures for Greece
background: Greece's prolonged economic crisis, liquidity shortages, and capital controls impeded access to EU structural funds, necessitating urgent measures to utilize remaining 2007-2013 allocations and secure pre-financing for 2014-2020 programs. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to enable exceptional financial support through European Structural and Investment Funds for Greece.

stances.stance:
EFDD partially agrees the liquidity measures but demands immediate termination of austerity policies linked to cohesion funding.  
EFDD requests amendment to Article 2 to explicitly prohibit macroeconomic conditionalities affecting Greek social welfare programs.  
This firmly conflicts with EFDD's position that EU fiscal rules disproportionately target weaker economies while tolerating northern member states' deficits.
